body.p: Myosin is
Cardiac muscle cells differ from skeletal muscle cells because:

input.choice: They contain intercalated discs and gap junctions.

body.p: Skeletal muscle cells are generally multinucleate because:

input.choice: They were formed by fusion of more than one cell.
Their parent cells were also multinucleate and they formed this way through mitosis.
As neighboring cells experienced apoptosis, they absorbed the nuclei of those cells.

body.p: Smooth muscle cells differ from skeletal and cardiac muscle cells in that:

input.choice: They don’t require calcium for contraction.
They can’t shorten as much as skeletal and cardiac muscle can.

body.p: If people are given an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, they are likely to:

input.choice: More easily activate skeletal muscle contraction.

body.p: The benefit of the creatine phosphate is that:

input.choice: It provides stored oxygen for rapid ATP generation.
It can generate ATP for a short time even when oxygen is not present.
It acts as a fuel source in muscle cells.
It can make actin-myosin crossbridge formation more efficient, leading to greater force generation.

body.p: Force generation in a whole skeletal muscle would not be enhanced by:

input.choice: Starting at the muscle's optimal length.
Stimulating the motor units at a higher frequency.

body.p: Skeletal muscles can differ in the time it takes them to generate tension after a stimulus is applied. This is often the result of:

input.choice: The number of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
The rate at which action potentials are conducted along the sarcolemma.
The size of the individual muscle fibers.
Whether the fiber types are oxidative or glycolytic.

body.p: While performing pull-ups, a person slowly lowers themselves from the “up” position. This is an example of:
The property of muscle that gives it the ability to stretch without damage is :
Which of the following correctly lists the sequence of structures that action potentials must move through to excite skeletal muscle contraction?

input.choice: Sarcolemma, axon of neuron, T tubules
Muscle fiber, axon of neuron, myofibrils
Axon of neuron, sarcolemma, T tubules

body.p: Release of calcium from which of the following structures triggers skeletal muscle contraction?
The sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle fibers is used for storing:
Which of the following regions of a sarcomere contain(s) thin filaments?

input.choice: Both I band and A band
All of these answer choices are correct

body.p: Which of the following region(s) of the sarcomere contain(s) thick filaments?

input.choice: Both A band and H zone
All of these answer choices are correct

body.p: Myofibrils contain:

input.choice: All of these answers are correct.
None of these answers is correct.

body.p: Which of the following functions as a motor protein in all three types of muscle tissue?
What regulatory proteins can be found in the thin filaments of skeletal muscle fibers?
Which region(s) of the sarcomere contain titin?

input.choice: From M line to Z disc

body.p: Which of the following proteins is used to reinforce the sarcolemma and to help transmit the tension generated by the sarcomeres to the tendons?
During muscle contraction by the sliding filament mechanism, thin filaments are pulled towards the:
What energizes the myosin head?
Skeletal muscle contraction will continue to occur as long as which of the following chemicals are available in the cytosol of the muscle fiber?
To stimulate skeletal muscle contraction, acetylcholine must cross the __________ of the neuromuscular junction and bind to receptors on the motor end plate.
Which of the following are commonly used to produce ATP during skeletal muscle contraction?

input.choice: All of these choices are correct.
None of these choices is correct.

body.p: In skeletal muscles, the combined amounts of creatine phosphate and ATP provide enough energy for the muscle to contract maximally for approximately:
Which of the following structures consists of a somatic motor neuron and all the skeletal muscle fibers it stimulates?
A brief contraction of all muscle fibers in a motor unit in response to a single action potential moving down the somatic motor neuron is known as:
Which of the following is also referred to as the period of lost excitability in skeletal muscle fibers?
A period of sustained skeletal muscle contraction in which individual twitches cannot be detected is called:
Increasing the number of active motor units within a skeletal muscle is called:
Which of the following is the least powerful type of skeletal muscle fiber?
Which of the following microscopic structures is found only in the cardiac muscle tissue?
Which of the following types of muscle tissue contract(s) when excited by its/their own autorhythmic muscle fibers?

input.choice: All of these choices are correct.

body.p: Smooth muscle tone is maintained by the prolonged presence of ______ in the muscle cell’s cytosol.
Which is a correct sequence of events in the onset of rigor mortis?

input.choice: Cellular membranes become leaky -> myosin heads bind to actin -> calcium ions leak into the sarcoplasm -> muscles are in a state of rigidity
Cellular membranes become leaky -> calcium ions leak into the sarcoplasm -> myosin heads bind to actin -> muscles are in a state of rigidity
Myosin heads bind to actin -> cellular membranes become leaky -> calcium ions leak into the sarcoplasm -> muscles are in a state of rigidity
Calcium ions leak into the sarcoplasm -> cellular membranes become leaky -> myosin heads bind to actin -> muscles are in a state of rigidity
Calcium ions leak into the sarcoplasm -> myosin heads bind to actin -> muscles are in a state of rigidity -> cellular membranes become leaky

body.p: On which of the following proteins is the enzyme ATPase located?
Which of the following statements does not accurately describe aerobic cellular respiration in skeletal muscles?

input.choice: Pyruvic acid generated by glycolysis enters the mitochondria.
CO2 is produced as a waste product.
The process can be used to generate ATP from fats, proteins or carbohydrates.

body.p: Cross bridges are formed during muscle contraction when _____ on the thick filaments binds to ______ on the thin filaments.
In a neuromuscular junction, the effect of acetylcholine (ACh) binding to receptors on the motor end plate lasts only briefly due to:

input.choice: Rapid uptake of the ACh into the myofiber
Endocytosis of the ACh receptor into the myofiber
Rapid destruction of ACh in the synaptic cleft by acetylcholinesterase
Rapid destruction of ACh in the synaptic cleft by monoamine oxidase
Diffusion of the ACh out of the synaptic cleft

body.p: During which period of a twitch contraction does the muscle action potential move along the sarcolemma of the muscle cell and trigger calcium release into the sarcoplasm?
Which of following is a common characteristic of fast glycolytic (FG) skeletal muscle fibers?

input.choice: Low concentration of creatine kinase in the sarcoplasm
High amount of glycogen in the sarcoplasm

body.p: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder that targets the ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction and ultimately reduces the number of available receptors. Predict what will happen if you treat a patient who has myasthenia gravis with a drug that inhibits the activity of acetylcholinesterase.
Biceps are predominantly composed of which type of muscle fiber?
In an isometric contraction, the muscle develops tension but does not:
Which of the following is not properly matched with its level of organization?

feedback.p: Incorrect- Actin and Myosin are on the molecular level.
Correct. Sacromeres and myofibrils are on the microscopic level.
Incorrect. Fascicles are examples of the tissue level.
Incorrect. Skeletal muscle is an example of organ level.

body.p: Mature muscle increases in size by which process?

feedback.p: Incorrect. This is the process that leads to mature muscle cells.
Incorrect. This is the term for the fused myoblasts.
Correct. Hypertrophy is the process by which mature muscles increase in size.
Incorrect. Atrophy is the process by which mature muscles decrease in size.

body.p: Myoblasts in muscular system perform a similar function to _______ in the skeletal system?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Osteocytes are mature bone cells.
Incorrect. Osteon is a structure found in compact bone.
Correct. Osteoblasts build bone and myoblasts build muscle.

body.p: Calcium is used to trigger cross-bridge formation during which phase of muscle contraction?

feedback.p: Incorrect. In this phase Ca is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
Incorrect. In this phase the Ca moves out of the sarcoplasm.
Correct. During the contraction phase Ca will be used to trigger cross-bridge formation.
Incorrect. A myogram is a picture illustrating all of the phases of muscle contractions.

body.p: Which of the following is described as a condition in which successive stimuli produce a greater amount of tension, even though tension goes back to the resting state between stimuli?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Summation occurs when the effects of successive neural stimuli are summed, or added together.
Incorrect. Tetanus is a continuous fused contraction that does not decrease to the resting state between stimuli.
Correct. Treppe is a condition in which successive stimuli produce a greater amount of tension.
Incorrect. Recruitment is an increased in the number of motor units involved.

body.p: A triad consists of what components?

input.choice: Two T tubules and one terminal cisternae.
One T tubule and one terminal cisternae.
One T tubule and two terminal cisternae.
One scarcolemma and two T tubules.

feedback.p: Incorrect. These are the correct components but not the correct number of each.
Incorrect. Triad implies that there are three components.
Correct. A triad consists of one T tubule and two terminal cisternae.
Incorrect. The T-tubules are an extension of the sarcolomma.

body.p: How does Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) exemplify the relationship between structure and function in skeletal muscles?

input.choice: With too much dystrophin the sarcolemma is too flexible and this results in muscle fiber damage.
There is a lack of Ca++ ions and the muscles cells cannot contract.
Without sufficient dystrophin, muscle contractions cause the sarcolemma to tear, which causes cellular damage.
There is no relationship between structure and function in skeletal muscles.

feedback.p: Incorrect. In DMD there is a lack of dystrophin not too much.
Incorrect. In DMD there is a tear in the sarcolemma and too many Ca++ ions enter the cell causing damage.
Correct. The normal structure has dystrophin protien which helps the thin filaments of myofibrils bind to the sarcolemma and prevents tearing.
Incorrect. In anatomy and physiology there are strong connections between structure and function.

body.p: Which of the following is a structure that is not matched with its function?

input.choice: Parallel arrangement allows for the contractile fibers to shorten into a large bulge for movement.
Sphincter arrangement allows for the muscles to expand and contract in a circular way
Convergent attach at an angle and allow for more tension on the tendons.
Pennate are feather shaped and do not move their tendons far.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The parallel arrangement of fibers allows for a bulge to form during contraction.
Incorrect. The sphincter is a circular arrangement that allows for expansion and contraction.
Correct. Convergent attach at a single point and allow for different motor units to be stimulated.
Incorrect. Pennate are feather shaped and attach to their tendons at angles resulting in small movement.
